taking place at the reef.

1441.14.text:
And so, two kinda group
of organisms that are, that

1444.38.text:
really tend to battle it out
are the corals and the algae.

1447.91.text:
And so, and there's and the
corals have kind of a losing

1452.38.text:
proposition sometimes because
they don't grow as fast as

1454.35.text:
most of the seaweeds, but
as long as they can maintain

1457.52.text:
their live tissue, then
they have a fighting chance.

1460.83.text:
So the reason that these
herbivores, such as Diadema

1463.13.text:
and Parrot fishes are so
important, is they help to

1464.93.text:
keep basically, they help
to keep the seaweeds in check.

1469.30.text:
And that provides one more
justification for the long-term

1472.30.text:
studies that are conducted in
the Florida Keys.

1475.54.text:
With data that covers decades,
trends can be detected

1483.51.text:
The loss of one
species affects the

1485.88.text:
health of the entire
ecosystem; and the efforts of

1488.79.text:
one person can
affect the future

1495.13.text:
Sometimes we have to make,
we have to make sacrifices

1497.40.text:
and maybe not do
everything that we wanna

1500.10.text:
do whenever we
wanna do it.

1501.37.text:
And a good example of
that is in this system.

1504.10.text:
For example, I love to fish
and I love to eat seafood,

1507.51.text:
but I know the reality of what
it takes to get certain

1511.51.text:
products, not all but certain
products, to the table.

1515.51.text:
And I know the damage that
it causes, and so,

1519.52.text:
it's all about making
informed choices.

1523.45.text:
Valid and substantiated
data allow resource

1526.52.text:
managers and the public
to make informed choices

1531.40.text:
It takes time, effort and
resources for scientists to

1535.20.text:
collect these data, but the
information gained from such

1538.47.text:
field work is the cornerstone
for developing plans to

1541.91.text:
protect and conserve
the natural world around us.
